intro: Commiphora boranensis, commonly known as Boran’s myrrh, is a small to medium-sized evergreen shrub native to the Horn of Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing species. The plant is characterized by its aromatic resinous exudates, which are harvested from the bark and used in traditional medicine and incense. Its leaves are alternate, elliptical, and often have a waxy texture. Commiphora boranensis thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.
